This species is commonly found in urban and rural environments, where it plays a crucial role in the decomposition of organic matter, including carrion and feces. Lucilia sericata is known for its ability to quickly locate and colonize decaying organic material, making it a valuable indicator species in forensic investigations.

In addition to its role in decomposition, Lucilia sericata has also been used in maggot therapy, a medical treatment that involves the application of sterile fly larvae to wounds to promote healing and prevent infection. The larvae of this species are capable of consuming necrotic tissue, disinfecting the wound, and stimulating the growth of healthy tissue.

Overall, Lucilia sericata is an ecologically and medically important insect species that continues to be the subject of extensive research and study in various scientific disciplines.
